G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 and the cause of action arose in Berkshire County.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County Superior Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1 since the events giving rise to this action occurred in Pittsfield, Massachusetts.

*Mennonite Mut. Ins. Co. v. Chiavelli*,.raw_text: *Mennonite Mut. Ins. Co. v. Chiavelli*, 434 Mass. 374 (2001)
*Mennonite Mut. Ins. Co. v. Chiavelli*,.proposition: Defendant owed a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining his property and trees so as not to create an unreasonable risk of harm to lawful users of the adjacent public sidewalk.
*Mennonite Mut. Ins. Co. v. Chiavelli*,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the legality of a warrantless in-home arrest and application of the exclusionary rule to physical evidence and postarrest statements. It does not involve premises liability, landowner duties, tree maintenance, or risks to users of adjacent public sidewalks. Therefore it provides no authority on the duty of a landowner to maintain property or trees for the safety of sidewalk users.

*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.proposition: Defendant owed a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining his property and trees so as not to create an unreasonable risk of harm to lawful users of the adjacent public sidewalk.
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.support_reasoning: The case does state a general duty of a landowner to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition for lawful visitors, but it does so in the context of an interior freight elevator accident, not the maintenance of trees or conditions affecting users of an adjacent public sidewalk. The proposition specifically concerns a duty regarding trees and sidewalks, which this opinion does not address; thus it cannot properly be cited as authority for that more specific sidewalk/tree duty, even though it contains a broad premises-liability duty statement.
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.relevant_excerpt: Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.” Mounsey v. Ellard, supra, quoting Smith v. Arbaugh’s Restaurant, Inc., 469 F.2d 97, 100 (D.C. Cir. 1972), cert. denied, 412 U.S. 939 (1973). However, the defendant was “not obliged to supply a place of maximum safety, but only one which would be safe to a person who exercises such minimum care as the circumstances reasonably indicate.”

*Andrade v. Perkins Sch. for the Blind*,.raw_text: *Andrade v. Perkins Sch. for the Blind*, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 206, 208–09 (2007)
*Andrade v. Perkins Sch. for the Blind*,.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes a duty on landowners to act reasonably in maintaining trees and vegetation that may endanger adjoining public areas.
*Andrade v. Perkins Sch. for the Blind*,.support_reasoning: The opinion text provided concerns criminal convictions for sexual offenses and the trial judge’s use of Mass. R. Crim. P. 25(b)(2), along with reasonable doubt instructions. It does not discuss premises liability, landowner duties, or maintenance of trees or vegetation adjoining public areas. Therefore, it cannot serve as authority for the proposition about a Massachusetts landowner’s duty regarding trees and vegetation endangering public areas.
*Andrade v. Perkins Sch. for the Blind*,.relevant_excerpt: Rule 25(b)(2) and its statutory predicate, G. L. c. 278, § 11, offer a defendant, on motion after jury verdict, three options for potential relief: a new trial, a verdict of not guilty, or the entry of a verdict of any lesser included offense. The first and third of these are addressed, in some measure, to the sound discretion of the judge and permit the judge to consider, among other factors, the weight and sufficiency of the evidence.

*Wilbur v. Newton*, 302 Mass. 38, 39 (19.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes a duty on landowners to act reasonably in maintaining trees and vegetation that may endanger adjoining public areas.
*Wilbur v. Newton*, 302 Mass. 38, 39 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion is a zoning and nonconforming-use case about sand and gravel operations and buildings in a residential district. It does not address duties of landowners concerning trees, vegetation, or conditions endangering adjoining public areas. Nothing in the reasoning or holding discusses maintenance of trees or vegetation, so the case does not support the stated proposition about a duty to act reasonably in maintaining trees near public areas.
*Wilbur v. Newton*, 302 Mass. 38, 39 (19.relevant_excerpt: On this branch of the case the precise issue is whether it was, or is, so unreasonable and arbitrary to prohibit new buildings, other than residences, on or near the gravel bearing portions of the Wilbur and Esty lands as clearly to place such prohibition beyond the scope of legislative competency. No contention is now made in this case that the city can prevent the removal and sale of sand and gravel if no structures which violate the ordinance are erected or maintained.

*Foster v. Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: *Foster v. Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289, 291‑92 (1988)
*Foster v. Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to inspect, trim, or remove the visibly cracked and dangerous tree limb despite actual and constructive notice of its defective condition.
*Foster v. Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an employer’s duty in negligent hiring/retention of an employee with a violent criminal record in a bar environment. It does not address premises liability for trees, duties to inspect or maintain tree limbs, or issues of actual or constructive notice of a defective tree condition. Therefore it does not support a proposition about failing to inspect, trim, or remove a visibly cracked and dangerous tree limb.
*Foster v. Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “The doctrine states that an employer whose employees are brought in contact with members of the public in the course of the employer’s business has a duty to exercise reasonable care in the selection and retention of his employees… ‘Negligent retention… occurs when, during the course of employment, the employer becomes aware or should have become aware of problems with an employee that indicated his unfitness, and the employer fails to take further action such as investigating, discharge or reassignment.’”

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.proposition: Defendant breached this duty by failing to inspect, trim, or remove the visibly cracked and dangerous tree limb despite actual and constructive notice of its defective condition.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s breach of duty for failing to inspect or remedy a visibly cracked and dangerous tree limb with actual or constructive notice. Glidden v. Maglio involves a collapsed pump-jack scaffold on a roofing job and addresses causation and notice regarding an allegedly hazardous scaffolding or property condition, not trees or limbs. The court actually emphasizes that plaintiffs produced no evidence that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition, which cuts against a claim of breach based on known visible defects.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694 (2000.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs also produced no evidence tending to show that the defendant knew or should have known of any hazardous condition on his building. See Barry v. Beverly Enter-Mass., Inc., 418 Mass. 590, 593 (1994) (landowner who has no actual or constructive knowledge of allegedly hazardous condition so that it cannot reasonably remove or warn plaintiff of the danger, cannot be found to have violated duty of care).”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Defendant’s inaction constituted a failure to exercise the care that a reasonably prudent homeowner would have exercised under the same circumstances.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that Kask, as a homeowner, owed a duty of reasonable care regarding storage of firearms when allowing unsupervised access to a violent, mentally unstable person. However, the court explicitly leaves it to the jury to determine whether she actually exercised reasonable care and does not itself conclude that her inaction constituted a failure to exercise reasonable care. Thus, the case supports the existence of a duty, not that the defendant’s conduct was a negligent failure to meet that standard.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. … We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”

*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered bodily injury, pain and suffering, medical expenses, and lost income.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.support_reasoning: The case concerns governmental immunity and proximate cause in negligence claims against the Commonwealth; it does not establish any rule about the specific categories of damages (bodily injury, pain and suffering, medical expenses, lost income) resulting from negligence. While the facts describe that Officer Kent was shot and seriously wounded, the opinion’s legal analysis is about immunity and causation, not about what types of compensable damages flow from negligence. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the cited damages proposition.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.relevant_excerpt: “Officer Thomas R. Kent of the Leominster police department (Officer Kent) was shot and seriously wounded on September 15, 1995, by John J. MacNeil… The Kents argue that these acts and omissions foreseeably resulted in the shooting of Officer Kent.”

*Goldman v. Dennis*, 375 Mass. 197, 199.proposition: The damages sustained were foreseeable and within the scope of the risks created by Defendant’s negligent maintenance of the hazardous tree limb.
*Goldman v. Dennis*, 375 Mass. 197, 199.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns zoning regulation of condominium conversion of nonconforming cottage colonies and related equal protection and statutory authority issues. It does not involve negligence, hazardous tree limbs, foreseeability, or the scope of risk in a tort context. Therefore, it does not provide any authority for the proposition about foreseeable damages from negligent maintenance of a hazardous tree limb.
*Goldman v. Dennis*, 375 Mass. 197, 199.relevant_excerpt: “The legislative body of the town could reasonably believe that conversion of a cottage colony to single family use under condominium type ownership would encourage expansion of use beyond the short summer season. … Here the by-law is explicit in its limitation of the expansion of a nonconforming use. Although the limitation is phrased in terms of the type of ownership, we think it is valid as a regulation of ‘change of use.’”

*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.proposition: The damages sustained were foreseeable and within the scope of the risks created by Defendant’s negligent maintenance of the hazardous tree limb.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.support_reasoning: The opinion in Payton v. Abbott Labs concerns DES-related prenatal injuries and the availability of damages for emotional distress and prenatal torts. It does not involve trees, premises defects, or negligent maintenance of a hazardous condition, nor does it analyze foreseeability of damages in that context. The cited pages (548–49) focus on the requirement of physical harm for negligent infliction of emotional distress and the historical development of that doctrine, not on scope-of-risk or foreseeability related to falling tree limbs or similar hazards, so it does not support the stated proposition.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540,.relevant_excerpt: "A careful analysis of the cases dealing with emotional distress discloses an additional reason for denying recovery when there has been only negligent conduct and no physical injury to the plaintiff.... Where recovery has been allowed for emotional distress absent physical harm, the element of reasonable foreseeability usually exists.... We therefore conclude, on the basis of the proceeding analysis, that in order for any of these plaintiffs to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress, she must allege and prove she suffered physical harm as a result of the conduct which caused the emotional distress." (386 Mass. at 555–57)

*Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc..raw_text: *Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.*, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 633, 638 (2002)
*Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc..proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for all injuries and losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including medical costs, lost wages, and damages for pain and suffering.
*Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc..case_name: Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc.
*Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc..support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on duty, foreseeability, and summary judgment in a wrongful death/negligent hiring case; it does not discuss the scope or categories of compensatory damages available upon proof of negligence. The court merely recites that negligence requires duty, breach, causation, and damages, without specifying that recoverable damages include medical costs, lost wages, or pain and suffering. Thus, it does not provide authority for the detailed damages proposition stated.
*Coughlin v. Titus & Bean Graphics, Inc..relevant_excerpt: “Under Massachusetts law, to prove a cause of action founded upon negligence, the plaintiff must satisfy the elements of duty, breach, causation, and damages. See Bacon v. Federal Kemper Life Assur. Co., 400 Mass. 850, 853 (1987).”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 6C.proposition: Award interest and costs pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6C;
